headline: CNN Special Reports
subHeadline: The Murdaugh Murders: A Twisted Tale of Power and Money. Aired 11p-12a ET

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: 350 days a year and that he has no intention of slowing down.You can catch the entire conversations with him, as well as Mayor Adams and Meghan Trainor any time you want on HBO Max. Thank you for watching and please join us here on CNN every Sunday night to find out who is talking next.

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.sentences: The following is a CNN Special Report.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) UNIDENTIFIED 911 OPERATOR: Hampton County 911, what's your emergency?

utterances.speaker: ALEX MURDAUGH, ACCUSED OF KILLING WIFE AND SON
utterances.sentences: I need the police and an ambulance immediately. My wife and child have been shot badly.

utterances.speaker: RANDI KAYE, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Alex Murdaugh.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Double-murder mystery.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Soon to be on trial.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Alex Murdaugh facing charges accused of killing his wife and son.

utterances.speaker: JOHN MONK, REPORTER, THE STATE
utterances.sentences: This trial will be one of the most watched since O.J.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: For the first time, those closely tied to this shocking story sit down together.

utterances.speaker: MIKE HEMLEPP, ATTORNEY FOR SANDY SMITH
utterances.sentences: Every lawyer at this table is on trial.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN JINKS, CHILDHOOD FRIEND OF ALEX MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: It's a good feeling to be connected to the power.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Until it comes back to bite you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Powerful family, series of unsolved killings.

utterances.speaker: ERIC BLAND, SOUTH CAROLINA ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: How many families do you know that have five dead bodies in their orbit?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Murdaugh's housekeeper died in 2018 in a slip and fall at Murdaugh's home.

utterances.speaker: GINGER HARRIOTT HADWIN, SISTER OF GLORIA SATTERFIELD
utterances.sentences: He used Gloria's death to enrich himself.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: 19-year-old Stephen Smith was found dead on the side of the road.

utterances.speaker: SANDY SMITH, MOTHER OF STEPHEN SMITH
utterances.sentences: I want justice.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Good evening. I'm Randi Kaye.As Alex Murdaugh awaits his faith behind bars, many here in South Carolina and around the country are left with so many questions. Questions those close to the alleged crimes, which include financial fraud and murder, have been trying to answer. So tonight, for the first time, Alex Murdaugh's victims and alleged victims, their lawyers and local reporters who for years have been covering every detail of this case, come together to talk about the man who changed their lives forever and the mystery that has shaken this community. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: You're all brought together by really one man. But some of you, you do know each other, right, from --

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Our families worked together or went to school together.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: We're together, yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: There's always a connection.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: Always a connection some way. Yes.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: My father owned a grocery store for 54 years, which everyone came to that grocery store. That's what put me in the middle to be able to know everyone.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: We call him JJ.(LAUGHTER) KAYE (voice-over): Jordan Jinx, Ginger Harriott and Sandy Smith grew up in the rural county of Hampton, South Carolina. Less than 3,000 people live in the town of Hampton.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: One thing about Hampton also, I mean, genuine people live there. SMITHthey call you mom.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Hampton is also the hometown of Alex Murdaugh.(On-camera): What was Alex Murdaugh like as a young boy?

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Kind of rough. But typical friend. I mean, we were both interested in hunting and fishing and stuff like that.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: We were kids. I mean, we went to school together. So I just thought of him as Alex. He was, you know, out and he was just Alex.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Alex, he just seemed arrogant and conceited and like I'm better than you.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: You stayed friendly or in touch with him over the years?

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. I got wedding gifts from him. I gave him gifts. I went out of town and stuff he liked. I knew it, I brought it back. I mean, we were friends. I trusted him.KAYE (voice-over): Alex Murdaugh wasn't just a resident of Hampton. Alex's great grandfather, grandfather and father, Randolph Murdaugh III, had all been the county's district attorneys or what they call solicitors.

utterances.speaker: MANDY MATNEY, CREATOR OF MURDAUGH MURDERS PODCAST
utterances.sentences: Being a solicitor in South Carolina is one of the most powerful positions in our legal system.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Mandy Matney, John Monk and Liz Farrell are all local journalists.LIZ FARRELL, CO-HOST OF MURDAUGH MURDERS PODCAST: People have trouble finding lawyers here because of the way the legal system works. You have to be careful about who you hire sometimes because of who they might be associated with.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Over a century ago, Alex's great grandfather, a solicitor, also started a local law firm. Formerly called Pieters, Murdaugh, Parker, Eltzroth and Detrick, or PMPED for short.

utterances.speaker: MONK
utterances.sentences: The firm is a plaintiffs' law firm which means it specializes in wrongful deaths, medical malpractice, suing big corporations on behalf of victims.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Monk has been reporting in South Carolina for nearly 50 years.

utterances.speaker: MONK
utterances.sentences: Because the Murdaughs know pretty much everybody in that county, they could count on getting juries that had the reputation of siding with them in a big way.[23:05:11] MATNEY: Something that people don't understand about PMPED and their control over Hampton County, most names that I've looked up in the Hampton County public index, so many of them have lawsuits connected to PMPED. Everybody has a cousin who's gotten a lot of money from calling PMPED and them handling a car accident, for instance. I've heard that a million times. KAYE (on-camera): Yes. It created a loyalty.

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: Yes. It creates a loyalty and it creates a -- like a culture of silence basically.

utterances.speaker: FARRELL
utterances.sentences: Yes. For sure.KAYE (voice-over): Alex Murdaugh, a lawyer himself, worked at his family's law firm PMPED since he graduated law school back in 1994. Mike Hemlepp, Justin Bamberg, Joe McCulloch, and Eric Bland are all local litigators. (On-camera): All four of you graduated from the University of South Carolina School of Law, correct?

utterances.speaker: JOE MCCULLOCH, SOUTH CAROLINA ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Because Alex Murdaugh also graduated from the same school.

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: Randy and I graduated together.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: His brother?

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: Yes, his brother.

utterances.speaker: JUSTIN BAMBERG, SOUTH CAROLINA ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: Growing up, the Murdaughs, even over in Bamberg County, you know, people knew who they were.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: Randy, I have stories I will tell you. I was talking to a lawyer here in town who said his old law partner, who was a big political figure here in town, got a call one day from old Buster.KAYE (voice-over): Buster is the nickname of Alex Murdaugh's grandfather, a solicitor who served for 46 years.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: Buster said, Counselor, I know you can help me out here. My boy has gotten into some trouble. And he needs to be gotten out of it. And I know you can handle it. And so the lawyer jumped right on it and within an hour, he'd made the calls like we could do in the good old days and make problems go away. And he called Buster back and he said, solicitor, I got it taken care of. It's all gone. He said, what do I owe you? He said, solicitor, I don't need to be paid. You know, this is a favor. And he said, Buster then said to him, well, you know, Counselor, if you ever need to kill a man, you bring him to Hampton County.And whether that was true or false, maybe a joke, but that was the reputation. And that is what that community has dealt with for decades. JINKS: That law firm did a great deal for the county residents. But it doesn't give that law firm the right to have so much power to suppress law enforcement. You know -- KAYE (on-camera): That's what you think is going on here?

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Yes. And if the Murdaugh family did something wrong, they are guilty. (INAUDIBLE) or not. We ain't playing on a level playing field when it comes to Hampton County and the Murdaugh family.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: Your status in an environment, a town, should not exclude you from the law.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: You should -- if you do wrong, you should be punished like anyone else.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: You know, yes, I like being connected to the power for 50 years. I could pick up the phone if somebody is bothering me.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Until it comes back to bite you?

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Exactly.KAYE (voice-over): PMPED now named Parker Law did not respond to CNN's request for comment. (On-camera): The state grand jury has indicted Murdaugh on about 90 charges or so. In terms of schemes to defraud victims totaling nearly $8.8 million or so, he's also been indicted as you know on the two counts of murder in connection with the deaths of his wife and son. As lawyers practicing for quite some time in this state, what do you make of that?

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: Proud. Proud of our legal system. Proud of our attorney general. Proud of our judges. I mean --

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: I want to add something.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: I am not proud. I am angry. I'm very angry. You asked how we feel about this? Alex threw all of us under the bus. The entire world is looking at South Carolina and every lawyer at this table is on trial because of greed and avarice. I represent the family of a 19- year-old kid who was poor, who was brutally murdered and left on the side of the road. And who gave a crap about that in 2015?KAYE (voice-over): When we return --

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: They beat him to death.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: Now we know, there's missing evidence. KAYE

utterances.speaker: FARRELL
utterances.sentences: I had heard right after the murders that there were something on Alex's shirt.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: All circling Alex's orbit.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Maggie and Alex Murdaugh married in August of 1993. Around that time, they had two kids, Buster and their youngest son Paul. That's when they met Gloria Satterfield.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: We grew up close.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Ginger is Gloria's younger sister.(On-camera): How close was Gloria to the --

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: Very much. She baby-sat for them before she started doing the housekeeping. Paul was about 13 months old. He was just starting to walk. She would wear skirts all the time and he would walk around and hold her skirt while she was doing the housework and stuff. She pretty much raised him, him and Buster. She thought the world of Maggie.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Double murder mystery. This morning, investigators trying to find who killed two members of one of South Carolina's most prominent legal families.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: What about the murder of Maggie and Paul? What is it that has surprised you the most? What still shocks you?

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: Liz was one of the first people that called me that morning. And speechless, absolutely was the word.

utterances.speaker: FARRELL
utterances.sentences: Unbelievable. I started making calls because I was worried that right from that moment that already this is being covered up.

utterances.speaker: MONK
utterances.sentences: There were many different thoughts that filled my mind. I mean, a mother and her 22-year-old son being shot to death with two different weapons, apparently a shotgun and some sort of AR-15? You're thinking two people must have done it. Right? And so it became a big who done it. Maybe Alex did it. But if Alex did it, why did he use two guns?

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: The phone has kept me up at night. What is with Maggie's phone? How does that puzzle piece fit into all of this? KAYEcellphone had been found in the woods?

utterances.speaker: MONK
utterances.sentences: Right. About a half a mile away from the Moselle Estate.KAYE (voice-over): Moselle is what they called the 1700 acre hunting property where the Murdaughs had a home.

utterances.speaker: MONK
utterances.sentences: It just added to the strangeness. Why should somebody -- a killer apparently -- take the cell phone and drop it a half a mile away or a mile away by the side of the road?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: The feeling in the community, whoever killed the Murdaughs didn't end up here by accident or randomly.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: Crimes like this that don't involve robbery, statistically come back to a family member.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: Passionate crime.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: They were killed in a hail of bullets, each of them. And so that does suggest the passion that you mentioned.UNIDENTIFIED 911 OPERATOR: Hampton County 911, what's your emergency? A. MURDAUGH: This is Alex Murdaugh. KAYE (on-camera): He says he showed up at their property in Moselle and called 911 and found his wife and son bleeding. He reported them outside the dog kennels.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: The number one thing that stood out to me was the first time hearing the 911 call. The moment you call 911 and hit send on your phone, even though no one has answered and it's just ringing, it's recording on the dispatch end. And the phone is dead silent. And you can hear the dogs barking in the background. And as soon as dispatch answers, it's this panicked Alex.UNIDENTIFIED 911 OPERATOR: Hampton County 911, what's your emergency? A. MURDAUGH: This is Alex Murdaugh.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: I never knew panic could get caught on and off.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: Let the blabbering begin.A. MURDAUGH: I need the police and an ambulance immediately. My wife and child have been shot badly.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: That was so weird to me.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: You're saying he would have been panicked even before that, before it started -- before anybody picked up the line.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: That's really perceptive. I hadn't picked up on that.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: He would be hyperventilating.KAYE (voice-over): Evidence obtained by the state also allegedly places Alex, Maggie and Paul Murdaugh together at the scene of the crime more than an hour before Alex called 911. (On-camera): Some of the headlines that I could share from the two of you, high velocity impact spatter connects Alex to time and place of murders. That was in April of 2022. Maggie wasn't staying with Alex at the time. Sources say Alex lured Maggie to Moselle. This is all from your reporting.

utterances.speaker: FARRELL
utterances.sentences: I had heard right after the murders that there were something on Alex's shirt. And that it was significant.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: They may be looking at some evidence, including the potential of blood spatter on Murdaugh's clothing.

utterances.speaker: FARRELL
utterances.sentences: The only kind of body fluid that an investigator would find significant would be something that was small and would have come from a weapon.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Spatter is what actually puts him at the scene at the time of the killing.

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: What he had on him.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: If it's true.

utterances.speaker: FARRELL
utterances.sentences: Allegedly was something that you could have only gotten from one position.

utterances.speaker: MONK
utterances.sentences: I would just note with great respect and as a devil's advocate that those assertions, which may be true, have yet to be tested in a court of law with Alex's lawyers, who are some of the best in South Carolina.

utterances.speaker: DICK HARPOOTLIAN, ATTORNEY FOR ALEX MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Blood spatter? I know what I read in some blog. Never seen any blood spatter evidence.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: The unsolved double killings, just one of the many twists and turns deepening questions surrounding this powerful family.

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: One of the things that people outside of South Carolina don't understand about this entire story is somebody may read about it and they watch CNN and learn about it and feel like this happened quickly. It did not. This was a slow burn. It was like there was no bottom to the hole that was being dug.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: He is a guy that embodies the old saying, if you are going through hell, just keep on going.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: It's the onion that you keep peeling. You never get to the core.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes. Because it was like mind blowing. And I have been begging, you know. Nobody ever returned my call.KAYE (voice-over): Coming up --

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: You're talking about a young man who's homosexual. You're talking about a small southern town.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: It's taboo.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: Something didn't like it.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: And later --UNIDENTIFIED 911 OPERATOR: 911, where's your emergency? MAGGIE MURDAUGH, ALEX MURDAUGH'S WIFE: My housekeeper has fallen and her head is bleeding. I cannot get her up.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Longtime housekeeper for the Murdaugh family died after suffering some kind of fall at the Murdaugh home.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: To learn that he used Gloria's death to enrich himself is horrible.(COMMERCIAL BREAK) KAYE (on-camera): Share a little bit about your son Stephen.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: Laughing or smiling. KAYE

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes. He started at a tech school to become a nurse.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Did you know the Murdaugh family?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Stephen played little league one year and Randolph and Alex were his coach. You know, and that's how I met them. And then Stephen went to school with Buster.KAYE (voice-over): Buster is Alex Murdaugh's eldest son. (On-camera): The Stephen Smith case was reopened by SLED as a result of something that was found at the double murder scene for Maggie and Paul Murdaugh.

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: So Stephen died and he was found July 7th, 2015. Rumors were everywhere. Everywhere. This is a small county. It's impossible that people didn't know what happened. People talk.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: What the talk has always been was that Stephen had some sort of a relationship with a Murdaugh. And that that was going to get out.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: So they took him out?

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: Think how courageous Stephen was. You're talking about a young man who's homosexual, who isn't hiding it, is very proud of who he is. You're talking about a small southern town.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: It's taboo.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: It is taboo. And he's wearing it proud. And somebody didn't like it. It clearly had to have been related to his sexuality. Don't you believe, Mike?

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: A hundred percent. 100 percent. South Carolina and Wyoming are the only two states that have no hate crimes law.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: We have no hate crimes law?

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: No. We can't get one passed and we have been trying and begging and fighting.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: You are kidding me?

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: What happened to Stephen Smith?

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: There's so much we don't know. We know bare bones facts.UNIDENTIFIED 911 OPERATOR: Hampton County 911, what's your emergency?

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: We know that he was found at 4I was a prosecutor for a long time. But I have prosecuted cases of people having been hit by cars. This is not the scene of a hit and run. There was no debris.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: There was no debris. Lower extremities, nothing broken and his loosely tide sneakers were still on him, on his feet?

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: Could have been blown off.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: If it was a hit and run.

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: Every hit and run case I have ever seen, shoes blow off. They did not have their shoes on. A hit and run is extraordinarily violent. Extraordinarily violent. He had some abrasions but not significant.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: What do you remember about that night and when you learned what had happened to your son?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I was on my way to work. And I heard on the big dog radio that they had found a body in the road on Sandy Run and Joe Miley. And I was like, oh, gosh, my kids live on Joe Miley so I called Joel's house.KAYE (voice-over): Joel was Stephen's father.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Stefanie answered. I said, are you all OK? I heard something happened down the road. They found a body. And she said, mom, did Stephen spend the night at your house last night? I said, no. And then I knew. I knew it was him.KAYE (on-camera): Is that a mother's instinct?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. Yes. Because Stephen was my baby. So we were always close.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: And I know that soon after Randy Murdaugh had called.(Voice-over): Randy is Alex Murdaugh's brother.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: When I was on phone with Joel, he said, let me put you on hold because Randy Murdaugh is calling. He said, Randy wants to take Stephen's case pro bono. And I was like, what case? Because they said it was a hit and run.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Did you think that call from Randy Murdaugh was strange?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes. It made no sense to me.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Yes. And he's --

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I mean, really, there was no case there yet. JINKS

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: And his law office has said that he didn't call -- he didn't know Stephen had died until after the funeral.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Excuse me, but Alex Murdaugh and Randy Murdaugh were standing at the crime scene.

utterances.speaker: ALAYNIA SPOHN, REPRESENTED BY ALEX MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: SPOHN
utterances.sentences: At the crime scene.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: His office says that he never officered to represent the family in any way.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Well, if you can believe anything a Murdaugh says.(LAUGHTER) KAYE (voice-over): SLED has released some of the interrogations and interviews regarding Stephen's case to the media.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I don't feel like it's a hit and run. I've looked at the body itself.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You know, a lot of people seem a little nervous to say the name Murdaugh.KAYE (on-camera): The lead investigator at the time even voiced his doubts about this being a hit and run.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Typically you don't see the highway patrol working a murder. And that's what this is.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: That was the lead investigator at the time. Yet you still don't have answers and you still don't know who did this.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: This is either an extreme amount of corruption from very powerful people who were able to pull all of these strings, or everybody involved in this did not do their job, and that is very scary for the justice system, too. Both sides, it's scary.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: What do you believe happened to your son Stephen?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I feel like they beat him to death because the only damage was to his head. And he did have some defense wounds. He had a dislocated shoulder. It had to be somebody he knew to put his body like he was walking home.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: I mean, my heart goes out to her. This is hard to believe.KAYE (voice-over): It's been seven years and Stephen's case is still unsolved. His mother's attorney has yet to bring a case against the Murdaugh family.

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: There's no fact that I can point to other than talk, rumors, speculation and the connection of the SLED reopening the case at Mossell. There's nothing connected to the Murdaughs. And I'll tell you the other thing, there are people right now in Hampton who know what happened. And they need to come forward.

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: Sandy lost her son but she is also lost her community because people were just turning their back saying, we can't say anything.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I want justice for my son.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: You deserve it.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: You deserve it. You do.
